awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: Big Data Analytics: Elucidation of Volatile Organic Compounds in Urban Atmosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (PRF) is directed towards the development of a system for integrating large amounts of data using machine learning algorithms to provide new insights into the understanding of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the urban atmosphere. The results of this effort are expected to help regulatory agencies estimate emissions from non-traditional sources of VOC in the atmosphere and improve the overall accuracy of emission inventories.

The objectives of this research focus on: (1) categorizing emitted (primary) and chemically formed (secondary) VOCs from comprehensive measurements; (2) investigating local (vehicles, indoor, industry, landfill, etc.) and regional (wildfire, ocean, etc.) origins of primary VOCs; (3) identifying the dynamic and spatial hotspots of specific VOC emissions; (4) understanding the implicit and nonlinear relationships between primary VOCs and their secondary VOC products; and (5) the influence of environmental factors on primary VOC degradation and secondary VOC formation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Air pollution is the fifth-ranking human health risk globally. Toxicological and epidemiological studies suggest that many severe diseases are closely associated with air pollutants, such as fine particulate matter, nitrogen oxides, black carbon, ozone, methane, and other air toxics. Recent data released by the World Health Organization (WHO) reveals that approximately 4.2 million deaths occur every year because of air pollution exposure, and over 80% of people live in urban areas where air quality often exceeds the standards. Thus, understanding the key factors for air pollutant variations and impacts across all types of communities with small-scale resolution is crucial to assess human exposure in urban environments.

 

However, urban air pollution is challenging to interpret by measurements alone due to the highly complex sources and transformation processes. Therefore, in this work, we developed an environmental object-oriented programming (EOOP) system which integrates big data analytic methods, machine learning algorithms, and self-developed algorithms to apply to urban air pollutant measurements to reveal spatial and temporal emissions and processes. After developing this framework, we applied it to real-time spatial-resolved urban air pollution measurements to test the system, with a focus on the improvement of hotspot source signature identification and determining the key environmental factors that are important for the pollutants.

 

Through the combination of mobile measurements in an urban environment (San Francisco, California) and the big data analytics, we show that complicated pollutant-factor relationships can be uncovered, and the relative importance of different factors can be quantitatively compared. Specifically, we found that emissions from heavy traffic roads are still substantial. In addition, pollutants are also largely accumulated in regions with high daytime population activities and dense businesses with even higher concentrations than vehicle emissions. Cooking and the related natural gas leakage are also suggested to be important pollutant sources. We also found that pollution inequity exists in the communities with lower vehicle possession rates which experience higher burdens of air pollutant exposure. The broader impacts of the project are that the findings from this project suggest that air pollution mapping in small spatial scales and coupled big data analytics are necessary for assisting policymakers to identify locations with high environmental inequity, developing equitable adaption solutions for all types of urban communities, and providing guidance to address environmental exposure concerns.
